column1: - Soy-based formulas should be used for infants with galactosemia, a rare condition.
These formulas can also be used for babies who can't digest lactose, which is uncommon in children younger than 12 months.

Hypoallergenic formulas (protein hydrolysate formulas): - This type of formula may be helpful for infants who have allergies to milk protein and for those with skin rashes or wheezing caused by allergies.
- A child who has an illness with diarrhea usually will not need lactose-free formula.
- Special formulas may be used for infants with heart disease, malabsorption syndromes, and problems digesting fat or processing certain amino acids.
Your baby will have a slightly different feeding pattern depending on whether she is breastfed or formula fed.
Infant formula can be used until a child is 1 year old.
The AAP does not recommend regular cow's milk for children under 1 year old.
